DataElement.preferredName: Tumor Identifier Domain Neoplasm Longest Diameter Measurement CDISC Variable Terminology Outcome
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The numerical value of the longest diameter of the tumor measured.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Tumor Identifier Domain Neoplasm Longest Diameter Measurement
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A domain that represents the data that uniquely identifies tumors.:A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias._The longest possible length of a straight line passing through the center of a circular or spheroid object that connects two points on the circumference.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A domain that represents the data that uniquely identifies tumors.

Concepts.definition: A domain that represents the data that uniquely identifies tumors.

Property.preferredDefinition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.:The longest possible length of a straight line passing through the center of a circular or spheroid object that connects two points on the circumference.

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant tissue growth resulting from uncontrolled cell proliferation. Benign neoplastic cells resemble normal cells without exhibiting significant cytologic atypia, while malignant cells exhibit overt signs such as dysplastic features, atypical mitotic figures, necrosis, nuclear pleomorphism, and anaplasia. Representative examples of benign neoplasms include papillomas, cystadenomas, and lipomas; malignant neoplasms include carcinomas, sarcomas, lymphomas, and leukemias.
